facts.text: Appeals arise out of an order of discharge passed by the Subordinate Judge-Magistrate of Dhanbad under s. 494 CrPC consenting to withdrawal against appellant Mahesh Desai

anchor.surface_text: Jagannadhadas, J. These appeals arise out of an order of discharge passed by the Subordinate Judge-Magistrate of Dhanbad under s. 494 of the Code of Criminal Procedure on his companysenting to the withdrawal of the Public Prosecutor from a prosecution pending before him in so far as it was against the appellant Mahesh Desai, one of the accused therein.

facts.text: Prosecution launched on first information of Ram Naresh Pandey against 28 persons for commission of murder of Nand Kumar Chaubey

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution was launched on the first information of one Ram Naresh Pandey as against 28 persons about the companymission of the murder of one Nand Kumar Chaubey, a peon of a companyliery in Bagdigi, companymitted in the companyrse of a serious riot on February 20, 1954.

facts.text: Murder of Nand Kumar Chaubey committed on February 20, 1954 in course of serious riot

anchor.surface_text: about the companymission of the murder of one Nand Kumar Chaubey, a peon of a companyliery in Bagdigi, companymitted in the companyrse of a serious riot on February 20, 1954. This was said to have resulted from differences between two rival labour-unions in companynection with a strike.

facts.text: Nand Kumar Chaubey was a peon of a colliery in Bagdigi

anchor.surface_text: the murder of one Nand Kumar Chaubey, a peon of a companyliery in Bagdigi, companymitted in the companyrse of a serious riot on February 20, 1954.

facts.text: Riot resulted from differences between two rival labour-unions in connection with a strike

anchor.surface_text: This was said to have resulted from differences between two rival labour-unions in companynection with a strike. The prosecution as against most of the other persons is under various sections of the Indian Penal Code, including s. 302, on the ground of their actual participation in the companymission of the murder.

facts.text: Prosecution against Mahesh Desai under s.302/109 IPC for abetting murder by speeches and exhortations day previous to murder

anchor.surface_text: But as against the appellant, Mahesh Desai, it is only under s. 302/109 of the Indian Penal Code, the part ascribed to him in the first information report being that he abetted the murder by reason of certain speeches and exhortations at meetings or group-talks the day previous to the murder.

facts.text: Application for withdrawal against Mahesh Desai made by Public Prosecutor on December 6, 1954

anchor.surface_text: The application for withdrawal as against the appellant was made on December 6, 1954, when the matter was pending before the Magistrate in the companymittal stage and before any evidence was actually taken.

facts.text: Withdrawal application at committal stage before any evidence taken

anchor.surface_text: when the matter was pending before the Magistrate in the companymittal stage and before any evidence was actually taken. It was made by the Public Prosecutor on the ground that on the evidence available it would number be just and expedient to proceed with the prosecution of Sri Mahesh Desai and that therefore it was necessary to withdraw the case against Sri Mahesh Desai only.

facts.text: Public Prosecutor applied for withdrawal on ground of meagre and dubious evidence against Mahesh Desai

anchor.surface_text: It was elicited in the companyrse of the arguments before the learned Magistrate that the position of the Public Prosecutor was, that the evidence regarding the companyplicity of this accused was meagre and that there was only a single item of evidence of a dubious nature against him which was number likely to establish a prima facie case.

facts.text: Magistrate granted consent and discharged Mahesh Desai

anchor.surface_text: The learned Magistrate dealt with the matter in a fairly reasoned order and was of the opinion that there was numberreason to withhold the companysent that was applied for. He accordingly discharged the accused.

facts.text: Sessions Judge upheld discharge order on revision petition by first informant and widow of murdered person

anchor.surface_text: That order was upheld by the learned Sessions Judge on a revision petition against it filed jointly by the first informant in the case and by the widow of the murdered person.

facts.text: High Court set aside discharge and directed Magistrate to record evidence and consider prima facie case

anchor.surface_text: These private parties pursued the matter further and applied to the High Court in revision. The learned Chief Justice who dealt with it was of the opinion that the companysent should number have been granted. Accordingly, he set it aside. ... He, therefore, directed that the Magistrate should record the evidence and then companysider whether it establishes a prima facie case against the appellant, Mahesh Desai.

facts.text: Advocate-General of the State appealed to Supreme Court against High Court order

anchor.surface_text: The Advocate-General of the State has companye up before this Court against the order of the learned Chief Justice.

facts.text: Mahesh Desai appealed to Supreme Court by special leave

anchor.surface_text: The aggrieved party, Mahesh Desai, also has companye up by special leave and both these appeals are disposed of by this judgment.

facts.text: Mahesh Desai held meetings and advocated closing Bagdigi cable plant and assaulting dalals as per FIR

anchor.surface_text: These persons, viz., Mahesh Desai and others, regularly held meetings and advocated for closing Bagdigi cable plant and companye plant and assaulting the dalals.

facts.text: On Friday morning, Mahesh Desai told labourers at Bagdigi to stop all work

anchor.surface_text: Yesterday, Friday morning when some labourers were going to resume their work in 8 No. pit at Lodna the striking labourers created disturbance there and the labourers of that place who were going to resume work companyld number do so. At about 11 a.m. Mahesh Desai the leader of the Koyala Mazdoor Panchayat came to Bagdigi and told the labourers of this place to stop all work, to hold on to their posts and to see that numberone worked.

facts.text: Mahesh Desai held meeting at 6:30 p.m. evening previous, exhorted labourers to prevent work resumption

anchor.surface_text: Last night at about 11-30 p.m. when I was in my quarter at Lodna, Jadubans Tiwary, the overman of Bagdigi Colliery, said that Sheoji Singh and Ramdhar Singh had told him that in the evening at about 6-30 p.m. Mahesh Desai came to Bagdigi Mahabir Asthan Chala, companylected 120 to 125 labourers and held a meeting and Mahesh Desai said that he had companye to know that the companypany and its dalals would take some labourers to pit No. 10 this morning to resume the work and they would get the work resumed by them.

facts.text: Mahesh Desai said to Phagu Dusadh, Jalo Dusadh, Haricharan Dusadh 'It is necessary for us to finish the dalals for achieving victory. You remain prepared for this.'

anchor.surface_text: Then Phagu, Jalo and Haricharan Dusadh of Bagdigi began to talk with him near the Jeep. Jadubans Tewary heard Mahesh Desai saying It is necessary for us to finish the dalals for achieving victory. You remain prepared for this. Saying this he boarded his Jeep and at the end Mahesh Desai said to Phagu, Haricharan and Jalo Dusadh Finish all. What will happen will be seen.

facts.text: Phagu, Jalo and Haricharan Dusadh chased Nand Kumar Chaubey and killed him with pharsa and lathi blows on day of riot

anchor.surface_text: The first information report companytinues to state what all happened the next day by way of rioting, etc. in the companyrse of which Phagu, Jalo and Haricharan Dusadh, along with others were said to have chased Nand Kumar Chaubey and wherein Phagu gave a pharsa blow and Haricharan a lathi blow to him and Nand Kumar Chaubey fell down dead.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside High Court order and restores Magistrate's discharge order

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion, for all the above reasons, that the order of the High Court should be set aside and the appeals allowed. Accordingly, the order of the trial companyrt is hereby restored.

facts.text: Prosecution still pending against other accused nearly three years after murder

anchor.surface_text: It is unfortunate that this prosecution which is still pending at its very early stages has got to be proceeded with against all the rest of the accused, after the lapse of nearly three years from the date of the murder.

arguments.claim: Consent under s.494 should not have been granted before recording evidence as there is evidence requiring judicial consideration; magistrate's procedure considered sufficiency prematurely, surrendering function to Public Prosecutor; s.494 does not justify such procedure; no judicial exercise of discretion.

anchor.surface_text: The question of law involved may be gathered from the following extracts from the learned Chief Justices judgment. This is not a case where there is noevidence on the contrary, this is a case where there is evidence which requires judicial consideration The procedure which the learned Special Magistrate followed was tantamount to considering the sufficiency or otherwise of evidence before the evidence has been heard The function of the Court would be surrendered to the Public Prosecutor. I do not think that s. 494 of the Code of Criminal Procedure justifies such a procedure.

arguments.qualifiers: normally High Court should not interfere but here no judicial discretion

court_response_anchor.surface_text: mbermally in a matter of this kind the High Court should number interfere. But he felt called upon to set aside the order on the ground that there was

arguments.court_reasoning: s.494 permits consent based on available material without full judicial determination or recording evidence; aligns with executive discretion and pre-trial magistrate functions

arguments.claim: High Court's view is based on erroneous appreciation of legally permissible approach under s.494 and likely to have repercussions beyond this case.

anchor.surface_text: The Advocate-General of the State has come up before this Court against the order of the learned Chief Justice. Leave was granted because it was urged that the view taken by the learned Chief Justice was based on an erroneous appreciation of the legally permissible approach in a matter of this kind and that the decision of the learned Chief Justice was likely to have repercussions in the State beyond what was involved in the particular case.

arguments.claim: Where withdrawal application is on ground of inadequate or unreliable evidence, court must exercise discretion only on judicially recorded evidence by holding preliminary inquiry or refuse consent and proceed under other discharge provisions.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the respondents has strenuously urged before us that while this may be so where the consent is applied for on other grounds, or for other reasons, the position would not be the same, where the application for consent is made on the ground of noevidence or not adequate or reliable evidence. It is urged that in such a case, the Court can exercise its judicial function, only with reference to judicially recorded evidence as in one or other of the appropriate situations contemplated by the Code for judicial inquiry or trial.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ondents has raised a fresh point before us for maintaining the order of the High Court setting aside the discharge of the appellant by the Magistrate.

arguments.court_reasoning: Engrafts impermissible exception/proviso on wide terms of s.494; court discretion on available material suffices without preliminary inquiry

arguments.claim: In Sessions triable cases, s.494 withdrawal application does not lie at committal stage as wording limits to 'cases tried by jury before verdict' and 'offences for which he is tried'; analogous to English nolle prosequi after indictment.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the respondents has raised a fresh point before us for maintaining the order of the High Court setting aside the discharge of the appellant by the Magistrate. The point being purely one of law, we have allowed it to be argued. His contention is that in a case triable by a Court of Session, an application by the Public Prosecutor for withdrawal with the consent of the Court does not lie in the committal stage. He lays emphasis on the wording of s. 494 which says that in cases tried by jury before the return of the verdict, and in other cases before the judgment is pronounced

court_response_anchor.surface_text: judicial determination or decision of a Court.  See Whartons Law Lexicon, 14th Ed., p. 545 . There is numberreason to think in the companytext of this

arguments.court_reasoning: s.494 wide and general; applies to all stages including inquiry/committal; no intended discrimination jury/non-jury; historical evolution confirms; s.333 for nolle prosequi; cites Giribala Dasee and Viswanadham

arguments.claim: s.494 vests general executive discretion in Public Prosecutor to withdraw subject to court consent determinable on many grounds.

anchor.surface_text: As the Privy Council has pointed out in Bawa Faqir Singh v. The King Emperor (1938) L.R. 65 I.A. 388, 395., It section 494 of the Code of Criminal Procedure gives a general executive discretion to the Public Prosecutor to withdraw from the prosecution subject to the consent of the Court, which may be determined on many possible grounds.

arguments.claim: Court's judicial discretion in granting consent under s.494 is to ensure Public Prosecutor's executive function not improperly exercised or abuse of justice process for illegitimate reasons; Public Prosecutor as officer of court provides fair view.

anchor.surface_text: The judicial function, therefore, implicit in the exercise of the judicial discretion for granting the consent would normally mean that the Court has to satisfy itself that the executive function of the Public Prosecutor has not been improperly exercised or that it is not an attempt to interfere with the normal course of justice for illegitimate reasons or purposes.

arguments.claim: Criminal justice scheme places primary prosecution responsibility on executive; magistrate's pre-trial discretions (ss.61,167,96,164,155(2),202) exercised on available material without prima facie determination; s.494 aligns with this.

anchor.surface_text: It has also to be appreciated that in this country the scheme of the administration of criminal justice is that the primary responsibility of prosecuting serious offences which are classified as cognizable offences is on the executive authorities... His discretion in such matters has necessarily to be exercised with reference to such material as is by then available and is not a prima facie judicial determination of any specific issue.

arguments.claim: Discharge resulting from s.494 consent need not conform to prima facie case standard under ss.209(1),253(1) or groundlessness under ss.209(2),253(2).

anchor.surface_text: For instance the discharge that results therefrom need not always conform to the standard of no prima facie case under ss. 209 1 and 253 1 or of groundlessness under ss. 209 2 and 253 2 .

arguments.claim: Public Prosecutor may legitimately apply for s.494 consent for reasons not confined to judicial prospects of prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: There is, however, a general concurrence - at least in the later cases - that the application for consent may legitimately be made by the Public Prosecutor for reasons not confined to the judicial prospects of the prosecution.

arguments.claim: Available material (FIR) indicates meagre evidence against Mahesh Desai based on hearsay; depends on few witnesses' exhortation evidence unlikely to sustain conviction; Public Prosecutor's view proper; no better material shown.

anchor.surface_text: It would be seen, therefore, that the prosecution must depend upon the evidence of Jadubans Tiwary, and possibly of Sheoji Singh and Ramdhar Singh and that what these three persons could speak to was at best only as to the exhortation made by Mahesh Desai at the various stages... Now, on this material, we find it difficult to appreciate why the opinion arrived at by both the trial court and the Sessions Court that the view taken of that material by the Public Prosecutor... should be said to be so improper

arguments.claim: Private complainants have no locus standi to participate in s.494 proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: There was some question raised before us as to whether the private complainants could be allowed to participate in these proceedings at the various stages. Nothing that we have said is intended to indicate that the private complainant has a locus standi.

holdings.text: It is not an improper exercise of discretion for the Court to grant consent under s.494 CrPC to withdrawal before evidence is taken, even if on ground of insufficiency of evidence, provided the Court is reasonably satisfied that the evidence is not likely to result in conviction.

anchor.surface_text: There is, however, a general concurrence - at least in the later cases - that the application for consent may legitimately be made by the Public Prosecutor for reasons not confined to the judicial prospects of the prosecution.  See The King v. Moule Bux A.I.R. 1949 Pat. 233  F.B. . and The King v. Parmanand A.I.R. 1949 Pat. 222, 226  F.B.   If so, it is clear that, what the Court has to determine, for the exercise of its discretion in granting or withholding consent, is not a triable issue on judicial evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wide language of s.494 does not permit engrafting exception for evidence grounds; aligns with executive discretion and magistrate's pre-trial functions on available material without prima facie determination; rejects HC view as impermissible construction.

holdings.text: Section 494 CrPC gives a general executive discretion to the Public Prosecutor to withdraw from the prosecution subject to the consent of the Court, which may be determined on many possible grounds.

anchor.surface_text: As the Privy Council has pointed out in Bawa Faqir Singh v. The King Emperor (1938) L.R. 65 I.A. 388, 395., It section 494 of the Code of Criminal Procedure gives a general executive discretion to the Public Prosecutor to withdraw from the prosecution subject to the consent of the Court, which may be determined on many possible grounds.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts Privy Council interpretation; no statutory indication limiting grounds; initiative with PP, court only consents.

holdings.text: The Court's function in granting consent under s.494 is to exercise judicial discretion satisfying itself that the Public Prosecutor's executive function has not been improperly exercised or is not an abuse of justice process for illegitimate reasons.

anchor.surface_text: The judicial function, therefore, implicit in the exercise of the judicial discretion for granting the consent would normally mean that the Court has to satisfy itself that the executive function of the Public Prosecutor has not been improperly exercised or that it is not an attempt to interfere with the normal course of justice for illegitimate reasons or purposes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: PP as officer of court provides fair view; judicial check prevents abuse without full trial determination.

holdings.text: The discharge resulting from consent under s.494 need not always conform to the standard of no prima facie case under ss.209(1) and 253(1) or groundlessness under ss.209(2) and 253(2).

anchor.surface_text: For instance the discharge that results therefrom need not always conform to the standard of no prima facie case under ss. 209 1 and 253 1 or of groundlessness under ss. 209 2 and 253 2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.494 aligns with pre-trial executive scheme, not inquiry/trial provisions requiring higher standards.

holdings.text: The application for consent under s.494 may legitimately be made by the Public Prosecutor for reasons not confined to the judicial prospects of the prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: There is, however, a general concurrence - at least in the later cases - that the application for consent may legitimately be made by the Public Prosecutor for reasons not confined to the judicial prospects of the prosecution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrence in later High Court cases; consistent with general discretion.

holdings.text: An application under s.494 for withdrawal lies in the committal stage of a Sessions triable case; the section is wide and general, applying to all stages including inquiry.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to construe s. 494 as involving any such limitation. The wording is perfectly wide and general and would apply to all classes of cases which are capable of terminating either in a discharge or in an acquittal, according to the stage at which the section is invoked.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual width; no discrimination jury/non-jury; historical evolution from 1872 Code confirms coverage of inquiry; agrees with Giribala Dasee and Viswanadham.

holdings.text: Nothing said indicates that the private complainant has a locus standi to participate in proceedings under s.494.

anchor.surface_text: There was some question raised before us as to whether the private complainants could be allowed to participate in these proceedings at the various stages. Nothing that we have said is intended to indicate that the private complainant has a locus standi.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Raised peripherally; no intention to confer locus in context of executive prosecution scheme.

holdings.text: The High Court order setting aside the Magistrate's discharge is set aside and the trial court's order of discharge under s.494 is restored.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion, for all the above reasons, that the order of the High Court should be set aside and the appeals allowed. Accordingly, the order of the trial court is hereby restored.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Magistrate properly exercised discretion on available FIR material showing meagre hearsay evidence unlikely to convict; trial and sessions courts correct; no impropriety.

anchor.surface_text: There is, however, a general concurrence - at least in the later cases - that the application for consent may legitimately be made by the Public Prosecutor for reasons not confined to the judicial prospects of the prosecution.  See The King v. Moule Bux A.I.R. 1949 Pat. 233  F.B. . and The King v. Parmanand A.I.R. 1949 Pat. 222, 226  F.B.   If so, it is clear that, what the Court has to determine, for the exercise of its discretion in granting or withholding consent, is not a triable issue on judicial evidence.

We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion, for all the above reasons, that the order of the High Court should be set aside and the appeals allowed. Accordingly, the order of the trial court is hereby restored.

We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion, for all the above reasons, that the order of the High Court should be set aside and the appeals allowed. Accordingly, the order of the trial court is hereby restored.

The holding on the court's function in exercising judicial discretion to check the public prosecutor's function directly addresses the issue of granting consent for withdrawal.

anchor.surface_text: There is, however, a general concurrence - at least in the later cases - that the application for consent may legitimately be made by the Public Prosecutor for reasons not confined to the judicial prospects of the prosecution.

We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion, for all the above reasons, that the order of the High Court should be set aside and the appeals allowed. Accordingly, the order of the trial court is hereby restored.

edges.explanation: Holding h6 directly addresses and rejects the issue i2 by affirming withdrawal under s.494 lies at committal stage

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to construe s. 494 as involving any such limitation. The wording is perfectly wide and general and would apply to all classes of cases which are capable of terminating either in a discharge or in an acquittal, according to the stage at which the section is invoked.

We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion, for all the above reasons, that the order of the High Court should be set aside and the appeals allowed. Accordingly, the order of the trial court is hereby restored.

There was some question raised before us as to whether the private complainants could be allowed to participate in these proceedings at the various stages. Nothing that we have said is intended to indicate that the private complainant has a locus standi.

We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion, for all the above reasons, that the order of the High Court should be set aside and the appeals allowed. Accordingly, the order of the trial court is hereby restored.
